												I'm really not a big fan of Tale of Tales, having played previous games like The Graveyard and that game with the deer, and now The Path. It's not because of their not-so-subtle pretentiousness, such as how when talking about the development of Sunset (their latest game, which I haven't played), they stated "Abandoning some of our more extreme artistic ambitions actually made work easier and more enjoyable. And that’s when we should have realized that we were on the wrong path. Because whatever we enjoy is never, ever, what the gaming masses enjoy." It's not because after Sunset became a commercial failure and they left the gaming industry, they proceeded to write a series of passive-aggressive statements on various mediums blaming Sunset's failure on the gaming community's inability to "get" it, along with a tweet that goes, and I quote, "Hahaha. I'm so free. Look at me. I can say ♥♥♥♥ GAMES! ♥♥♥♥ GAMERS! ♥♥♥♥ THE GAME INDUSTRY! DIE! DIE!DIE! And rot in hell!" It's not because in Michaël Samyn's Patreon, he has a $5,000 tier listed "Shut me up", claiming that "if you really want me to disappear from videogames altogether, stop writing about them but also stop trying to make them, basically get the f out of your precious hobby, all it takes is a bit of cash. Make my day!". Tale of Tales is a pretentious blowhard of a developer, and while any developer leaving the industry is a bad thing, I can't say I'll miss them. But none of those are the reason why.The reason I don't like Tale of Tales because they don't seem to have a clear grasp on what gaming is as an artistic medium. None of their games are good in the tratitional sense, and instead they bank on their artistic value. The problem is, their games never seem to actually acknowledge the strengths of the medium. Video games are a unique artistic medium because they allow the player to interact with the story and characters in ways that no other medium can easily do, and that allows them to give unique, involving, and emotional experiences that you can't get in other mediums. Tale of Tales games are more like paintings made into video games; they're pretty to look at, and maybe you can find a meaning if you look hard enough, but there's very little to actually see or do in them, and they don't really engage the player any more than going to an art museum would. Rather than being "games as art", these games are more like "art as games", and while I'm sure some people will appreciate them, they just aren't very fun to play at all, and I'm not so sure that they even wanted them to be fun. The Path is a game where you pick one of six girls and walk around a forest (or stay on the path, but you're pretty clearly not supposed to considering 98% of what little game there is is off the path), stopping occasionally to look at things, and that's basically it. You get to Grandma's house, and then you start over with another girl. It has a great atmosphere, and the forest environments are pretty to look at for the time it was released, but that's about as far as the game goes as far as what I can compliment.

												The Path is a walking simulator and adventure/horror game, where the horror mostly is implied.You take on the role of one of six sisters, each representing a different stage of womanhood, from little girl who only wants to play to a grown-up woman with adult wants.Each girl enters a path through the forest, at the other end of which is grandmother's house. Walk there, and the game for that girl ends.Of course, that's not where the real gameplay is. Instead, go into the forest. A strange girl clad in white tries to guide you further away from the path, and strange white distortion on the edge of your screen guides your character to other spots. You can pick up flowers along the way (which do nothing but increase a counter -- really, you don't get a thing for picking them all up) and also find strange items. Some of these can be interacted with, many cannot as they are meant for another sister.Each item you can interact with gets added to the basket.Eventually you will find the Wolf. The Wolf takes on a form which is meaningful to the sister you're playing as, and leads her to her death. These deaths range from the obvious (little girl gets eaten) to  the vaguely implied (talent agent destroys her? Woodsman rapes her?) -- a lot of this is left to interpretation.After each wolf encounter the girl is back on the path, but the only way to go is move forward -- slowly, limping -- to grandmother's house. If you picked up the right items along the way the house becomes a kind of horror slideshow with distorted graphics and sounds reminiscent of what you found in the forest...It is a strange and unique game definitely worth playing. Just don't think you'll fully understand all of it.Also of note is that the game's demo is actually a fully separate "level", where you play as the Girl in White in a very different form of the forest. Fortunately it can be installed even if you own The Path.

												Just a warning. This game is obviously not for everyone. I know Steam is in no way related to Ps3, but if you know “Journey” the game or have played it and liked it then this is a lot like that. A really relaxing game when you don’t want a challenge, but something to reflect on. This is more for people who like artsy games. Some people call it pretentious and that’s fine to have that opinion. I personally have poured hours into this after long days and like to discover the symbolism and weave my own story with the pieces I find. There is really a lot you can figure out or imagine if you are into characters and stories.Basically this purely explorative. Just walk, run, look and observe. That’s all there is to it. Some people find this too basic, but I think there should be both complex and simple games out there. If you don’t like easy stories and easy games- then don’t get this. But if you’re like me and love a little exploration than this is for you. My only problem? The camera sometimes gets a little wonky when I’m observing. But it isn’t every time and it’s not like you’re going to be in one place for long. This game is otherwise beautiful!The game will tell you to stay on the path. But here is the moral of the story; if you take the road where everything is paved out for you, then you don’t earn any experiences and you don’t learn anything about life. Everything is too safe and you will never know real life. Going off the path leads you to both good and bad experiences. The story is going for a bit of a darker theme and some people might think it’s too dark, but I think you can interpret it as something a little bit less so. I don’t really want to get into spoiler territory, but I’ll just say this; death in these types of games doesn’t always literally mean death, but death to a part of a character’s personality or how they look at life. The real objective is to find each of the girls their own “wolf” which symbolizes different things. These wolves are the main even that will change their lives for better or worse. You decide. There are plenty of people who have come up with awesome theories. And that’s part of the fun!

The Path is an interesting, thought-provoking game that takes a lot of pleasure in making us wonder what a 'game' is and to which extent it can blend with other genres. Playing The Path is like reading a book: there is no voice-acting, you have to read the thoughts of the six main characters to understand who they are and the nature of their desires and fears. Sometimes, it is like playing a record: the eerie, yet beautiful soundtrack plays a decisive role in setting the atmosphere of the game. The Path is not a traditional horror game: it plays with the player's sensitivity. I personally had to close the game once because I was just afraid. Afraid of the paradox that the Path presents us with: if we take the safe path and  go to grandmother's house unharmed, nothing happens (even though the grandmother is quite terrifying in my opinion, but this is not relevant here). To 'beat' the game, we have to encounter the wolf. Its form is always different, sometimes surprising. It completes and ends the girl's path, and helps us understand her better. I am currently replaying the game to better understand what happens and sharpen my interpretations.The music, the graphics, plus the work on the shading, blended with the subtle characterization of Robin, Rose, Ginger, Ruby, Carmen and Scarlet, bring into being a wonderful game. One that moves deeply and definitely asks for your point of view to become whole.

I picked this title up as part of a Halloween horror bundle on Steam and can safely say it's certainly not of the horror genre. The Path is what many would call an artistic game in the most extreme sense.Most people's first reaction, mine included, was being confused as to what the goal or purpose of the title was. This you quickly come to find is a ruse. Remaining on the path brings you swiftly to your end destination and a game ending. The real goal, if it can be called that, is to collect 144 flowers as well as stumble across objects and areas of the game which trigger memories. Each girl has their own look, locations and encounter with the wolf which is about the only variety that is present.The primary themes are of violence, sexual abuse and child abuse. This of course is not shown directly, or even indirectly, but very subtle with much of the events being left to our own interpretation. I can safely say I was highly disappointed in this and hoped it would be the best out of the horror bundle it was a part of. I wouldn't recommend purchasing this at any price personally and to keep clear from it.

												First, this game has its merits.  It has great atmosphere and the graphics aren't bad and the gameplay itself is creative and thought-provoking.  But straight up, if you don't like games that have an inconsistent story that gives you no answers, The Path isn't for you.  If you like games that make you think...The Path probably still isn't for you.Tale of Tales as a developer has completely imploded their own fanbase with their behavior lately, yes, and it's really made me reconsider this game.  Originally I thought a lot of thought went into this game; the developers established Livejournal accounts for the characters, there are a lot of details in the game, the girls all have some sort of personality and it seems like there's a mysterious story unfolding behind all this.It sure SEEMS that way.But the thing is, if you set up a mystery that no one else can solve and then insist that they don't "get it" because it's ABOUT not solving the mystery, but about "appreciating" the "puzzle as it was left unsolved," then that sort of makes you sound deep and mysterious yourself.  It sort of shifts the focus from the creation and onto the creator, the only person who has any answers about the otherwise completely unintelligible piece of work.  And frankly, after their freakout, Tale of Tales definitely sounds like a duo way more interested in shifting attention onto themselves.And I was really committed to putting together the puzzle of The Path once.  I pulled apart the girls' Livejournals and was really baffled that their situation seemed to indicate that The Path was an experience they had...all the time?  Regularly?  And that their mother insisted they only go on the path itself by themselves??  It started to seem like the developers were not interested in creating some macabre version of hell or surreal depiction of time, but had set up characters they could pretty much do whatever they pleased with, as long as that gave them attention.Honestly, if you set up a game to seem all deep and mysterious with individual sad stories to piece together, but then roleplay your characters as just whatever, it sorrrrta seems like you actually got nothing to say.I didn't want to believe this was the case before, but after seeing their attitude about the failure of their game Sunset, their interest in only having a small (elite) fanbase, and their total disregard for making their games accessible to people, I just don't think the people behind Tale of Tales possess the sympathy and depth to create a game that demonstrates sympathy and depth.It was a huge disappointment.The Path is not deep.  The Path does not have secret answers or an underlying meaning.  The Path is just a very creative atmosphere, all dressed up with nowhere to go. 												So... This definetly isn't for everyone. This is an art game, and should be experienced with that in mind. Like all art, it becomes what it is at the line where the artist/s & viewer/participant meet. Yes, it is highly open for enterpretation, and some people hate that & crave conclusions, goals & answers. However, unlike what I would consider "failed" art, where it's just a matter of a pretentious pile of worthlessness you're asked to find your own (non existent) meaning in because the artist really didn't have anything to really bring to the table, this does work!When it comes to art games, I love the fact that you're not just watching something here, you are participating. Making choices where to go and what or who to interact with, and with which character. You are also asked to find your own meanings, associations and how to feel about it.I don't always enjoy slow paced art games, believe me. But this I did. I enjoy the beauty of it, the sombre feeling, the symbolism, the sometimes surprising thoughts the girls have upon finding places or things. And there is a lot to be found, both within the game world, and subsequently within yourself. I was pleasently surpised, and rather intruiged.I'm hesitant to recommend it though, because like I allready mentioned, it is not gonna appeal to everyone. Just know it is slow paced, not very scary if that's what you're after, but more atmospheric, in a David Lynch kind of way.My complaints are that there are some clippings and graphical glitches, but nothing really noteworthy for this type of game. Also the music may get a bit repetetive and get on your nerves if you sit through too long a session, I would have prefered it a bit less vocal & more ambient, but it's no big issue. However, the color of the text in game *is* a real issue though, because many times it is near impossible to read against the background. That's a real shame because those texts are some of the things you long for the most in between the wandering in the forest, and aim to have show up to enhance your story & get more of the girls personalities.But over all, I thought it was a remarkable experience. Also, just have to add, that I loved the setting and design within the frame of Little Red Riding Hood! An excellent choice for artistic, emotional and psychological experiences.SPOILER! For those who like to theorise: I do believe, like many others, that this is a story about growing up. Some elements of this can be found in the tales of Little Red Riding Hood as well, so it's rather fitting. I see it as how we loose something as we grow, but it's inevitable. To "win" the game, you have to make each girl meet her wolf, and "die" a little. If you just go straight to grandma's house, you're there safe and sound, but you haven't learned anything. Each girl represents a different age, the youngest one makes comments about how she is a kid, she's a kid, and it reminds me of how some children want to play baby even though they are too young really. Like when a sibling shows up and they are suddenly the older one who needs to grow up. Likewise the older ones are starting to get interested in alcohol and sex, yet still being naive. They think they want a certain thing but it costs to know these things/experience them.

												I'm pretty open-minded when it comes to indie games, and I have a real fondness for less conventional games like Dear Esther and Gone Home. But The Path seriously pushed me to my limits of tolerance on this front. It's a game that is very obviously trying too hard, and lets its own mechanics get in the way of whatever point it's trying to make. Be warned, if you're going to give this one a chance at all, go play it yourself and come back because I'm going to spoil the hell out of it. I'm sure it's even less effective if you know what to expect.You pick one of six girls fresh from Hot Topic to visit their grandmother in the woods. The game tells you up front to stay on the path, and here it commits possibly its greatest sin. My first time through I made the slow walk straight down the path to a surprisingly sinister house. Inside the pitch-black cottage the girl made her way to her corpse-like grandmother and laid down next to her. The game then informed me that I had found no items, unlocked no rooms, not encountered the wolf, and that I had failed.So, to reiterate, the game told me to do a thing, I did the thing, and then it told me I failed.YOU CAN'T DO THAT YOU ♥♥♥♥S. If subversion of authority is a theme of your game then you need to introduce it in some way within the body of the game! I'm not going to read your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed treatise on your store page to figure out how to play your game. Fine, whatever, I picked another girl and walked straight off the path. The lighting and sound get creepy until you run across some random point of interest in the woods, like a theater stage or sofa or TV or pond. There are items to collect like knives and two-headed teddy bears. I met a little ballerina girl who spouted some nonsense about chaos and led me back to the path. After a whole bunch of exploring I went back to grandma's house. I got treated to a slightly different path through the rooms and then another screen that said I failed.At this point I gave up trying to figure out what the game wants. Wandering the woods is interesting for a bit, but hamstrung by the glacial speed at which you move and the horrible sketchy-artsy filters the game vomits all over your view. There's really no common theme or identifiable symbolism to the junk you find, either. It's just weird for the sake of being weird. Or maybe it isn't... the store page says the optimal experience is to play for 6 hours. There are something like 13 items to collect and another 144 flowers you can pick, but I doubt very much I'm going to divine The Path's true meaning if I keep at it.Appropriating the creepy side of Red Riding Hood isn't a bad idea for a game, but this one gets so caught up in trying to be clever and poignant that it all falls completely flat. Maybe there's something to find in here, but it's too damn boring and obtuse to get at it.

												If you're looking for action and adventure, don't buy this game. If you're looking for jumpscares, don't buy this game. But if you're looking for subtle tension, thoughtful and ambiguous themes, implied and frankly somewhat disturbing horror, and beautiful art, buy this game. It's an atmospheric game, and the developers create the atmosphere perfectly. Oh and if you're afraid of thinking, this game isn't for you.You begin in an apartment where you can pick one of six sisters. Each sister has different items you can interact with in the forest/a different wolf (not a literal wolf except in the case of the youngest sister, Robin). Each encounter could be interpreted many different ways. Personally I think that it's a loss of innocence story. Each girl meets something that they must face as they move into adulthood. The wolf is the most important part of the story. Once you reach the end of a girl's story, you will be told "success" or "failure" based upon whether or not you met the wolf (meeting the wolf=success). You also get a rating based upon how many of the girl's individual items/secret rooms you found.I've played for an hour and that's enough time to meet the wolf with two girls and collect about half of their items. However, you can spend hours in this game if you have enough patience. There are tons of different disturbing endings you can get based on which items you collect.Do note that the game is not "complete" until you've found the wolf which each sister (by leaving the path) and then walk the path with the girl who presumably represents childhood innocence. Then the game restarts and you can try again with a girl you've already found a wolf with.Overall it's not a fun game. It's a thinking and patience game that tells its story with beautiful art and excellent atmosphere. It's a great work and easily worth $10.

												Right off the bat, I’ll say you as the player will either love this atmospheric exploration game or it’ll really wear on your patience fast. It can be mind-numbingly slow, confusing, and the controls are tolerable at best. There is almost no gameplay beyond exploration and collecting to speak of. Still I do recommend this game very highly to exploration lovers, role-players, and players with active imaginations. For these players I promise this game will have a lot of the things they enjoy in gaming.Honestly, while I do highly recommend this game as stated above for open-minded players and exploration lovers. Personally, I found this game initially to be rather boring and hard to get into. As I tend to play more direct story driven and action oriented games. Yet, I decided to give The Path the play time I needed to honestly judge it. Out of sheer determination fueled by the other good reviews. Which generally said the game would get better if given time. For which was true in my case. I slowly started to get into this game as my predetermined notions of what makes good gameplay faded with each step I took into the dark woods. I quickly realized this game almost requires at least an hour or two to really judge it. Due to the game’s slow placing and subtle influences.None of the game’s story line is directly force upon the player and is instead left to them to find and figure-out. While, initial gameplay as stated above may leave the gamer lost and confused. Once they do discover their story oriented purpose in game, either through sheer luck or logical deduction. Story-driven events will start to playout more often for them and the story should start to become clearer in their mind. Leading to the player’s enjoyment level most likely increasing or at least I believe so. As in my case, once I got that ah-ha! moment I started enjoying myself. I have on purpose been rather vague with the details for those who do not like spoiler reviews so far. But for those who would like more to go off of. When deciding whether to give this interesting game a go or would like to just know more of what’s really going on in it. The follow two sections go into more descriptive detail. The first covers the gameplay elements and “generically” describes the goal of the game. The second further down one describes the games goal in-depth and does contains some direct story spoilers. Each section is tag with a warning label for those who rather avoid spoilers. If you choose to read on or not thank you very much for taking the time to read my review. - Olyth--- WARNING: Gameplay related spoilers below ---This game is ulitmately very dark and twisted. From the start you’re given two important choices to make. One which is obvious: Which of the young ladies would you like to play? The other, which is subtly hinted at: Is your chosen maiden going to be a good girl by following the given directions to head straight to her grandmother’s house without deviation or is she going to venture off the beaten path and explore the dark woods?So logic would dictate initially you of course would obediently follow the directions you’re given and go straight to grandma’s house without deviation, right? Oh, how obedience in this game is so overrated. All you’ll get for your goody-two-shoes effort is a whopping “D” rating as your character arrives to sit at the bedside of her dead-looking grandmother. While the words “FAILURE” is plastered across your screen. Before the game unceremoniously plops you back on the character selection screen. Yep, the game wants your little Miss to be a disobedient minor. If you hope to receive anything above a “D” rank and some acknowledged “SUCCESS!”Now if you’re girl does like to venture on the wild side and decides a little trip in the woods would be fun. Things are going to get a tad dark and atmospheric. As the game’s bright and cheery visuals turn quickly into a dark and eerie wooded locale with some lite horror elements introduced to set the mood. Also, to make things more interesting within mere seconds of leaving the path you’ll be completely lost and finding yourself walking in circles. Sounds like fun right? Well yes and somewhat no.Wondering the woods lost is basically the initial core of the gameplay. As the girl explores she’ll come across random items and some limited interactions with other characters. Which is intended to give the player hints and imagery to build upon to develop their own personalize interpretation of the game’s story. Which not surprising will make the initial experience very confusing. Borderline leading to some to rage quit out of frustration and boredom.  As they will be most likely waiting for the game to give them a purpose or at least a goal to work towards. Something the player may gain either within a few minutes or may take upwards of an hour or two to figure out. If they stick around long enough. Depending on a little luck and a lot of patience.After the player finishes his or her first character’s playthrough in the woods, either by coming across a key event or staying lost and running out of time. The goal of the game kind of becomes clear to the player to a certain point. Which is to lead each girl one-by-one to their horrible demise. For which the player receives higher ratings depending on how many items they found and if they located the girl’s personal key event. I did say the game was dark and twisted.--- WARNING: Contains story related spoilers ---As I mention above the player is rated on whether the player choices to collect items and if they find the girl’s personal key event. By Now I sure you've most likely figure out from the game visuals and the fact that the girrls all wear red. This game is based off the Red Riding Hood Fable. So the key event the player is ultimately looking for to get the best rating is to locate the other main character in the red-riding hood story besides Red and Grandma. The big bad wolf who wants to eat the young maiden. Pretty obvious huh, if you think about it. Yep, what you’re now thinking is correct: the player’s ultimate goal to get the best rating is to systematically hunt down the wolf and sacrifice their poor character to him. With each girl’s experience in the process being unique and the wolf being a little different for each of them. Due to girls being of different ages and having their own personalized perspective of the events as they encounter them.As the player finds girl’s personalize beast, they get to watch some unique cut-scenes of Red's and the wolf's initial encounter. Some being more entertaining than others. Before being taken to just outside their grandma’s house and allowed to enter it. Although, this visit is not as visually cheery as the good girl’s visit. Each girl gets their own twisted nightmarish version of the house to briefly tour. Before the player is shown the girl’s fate in the form of multiple image stills depicting their gruesome death by the big teeth and claws of their wolf. Followed by the player receiving a chapter completion prompt with that “SUCCESS!” they were looking for and an overall ranking as describe above. Afterwards, the player is returned to the character screen to select their next victim. With the deceased girls no longer being present alluding to the horrors that befell them. Now what happens, when only a few girls are left or better yet; none…..? Is there something sinister going on behind the scenes. Maybe something to do with the memories and visions the girls saw. Well I going to leave that’s for the player to figure out; enjoy! Thanks again for reading my review/overview.

												This is a very hard game to quantify into a catagory, genre group or ranking. Not truely a game, but not enough of an indie classic to be called "art"; to me it stands on its own as a psychological examination of life and what it means to mature from childhood to adulthood for the six sisters of this thriller/horror interactive piece.You have one objective: get to grandma's and do not leave the path. But unfortunately the message isn't as clear as it could have been without being a completionist or cheating and hitting GameFAQs for a plot synapsis.As an art deco title, it's a game that must be played at least once in your life. English Literature and Psychology Majors will get a real kick out of this title, as well people with an interest in slow-paced thriller and horror games. The times you have to walk the last stretch to Grandma's house are agonizingly slow.There's supposed to be an action button, but I generally was only able to interact with things by approaching them until a ghostly closeup appeared in the window, then taking my hand off the controls. Having actions happen when controls aren't being manipulated is TERRIBLE interface design.And then there are the location indicators along the outside of the screen. Given that most of the forest is empty, this is your primary means of locating the things you're looking for. But it doesn't respond quickly, it's hard to judge distances, and the map only pops up occasionally (!)I'm not going to even attempt to talk about The Path's artistic merits. But even if this were the world's most beautiful painting, you'd still be looking at it through a broken, filthy window from 300 feet away. The weakness of the interface makes the basic act of playing through the work tedious and unpleasant.I'd include a trigger warning for sexual violence imagery, but ... it's a freakin' Little Red Riding Hood game. 												Please note that The Path may not be everyone's cup of tea. It's not what some would consider a "game", but more of a story shrouded by symbolism and is incredibly artsy. If you hate games that are almost purely story driven and more of an experience, then you might want to look elsewhere.For a person like me, The Path is just the type of thing I love. Not only is there dark and mature themes, but the symbolism is absolutely brilliant if you notice them. I also enjoyed the "Red Riding Hood" theme the game had going for it. After replaying a few times and discussing the story with others, I realized the game is actually very open for a lot of interpretation. More so than I anticipated. The ideas that many have come up with have only enriched the experience for me.Basically, you have several sisters, each very different from each other, and their goal is to get to grandmothers house to deliver some goods. The rule is to not stray from the path, but it has to be broken in order for the girls to encounter the wolf. If you do not want to be spoiled or have my opinion on the wolves and their interpretation with each girl, please skip the next paragraph.In my opinion, each girl represents a stage of life. The wolves are an experience that one must go through to grow up. These experiences may be harmful or scarring, but like in the game, the girls get up, wounded, and make their way back to grandma's house. The whole story is about growing up. Letting your curiousity getting the better of you, getting wounded, but growing up a little. The path is a safe life without exploration. There is no harm, but neither do you learn anything. That is why you get a failure screen when you do not encounter the wolf.As for it's length, if you just buzz through the main task at hand, it is very short and you also miss a lot of added story. Each girl has items and unlockables. There is also 144 "flower coins" to collect if you so chose. In my opinion, the replay value only lasts as long as there is something that you missed, which just to note that the forest is randomly generated each time so finding everything will be a challange if you switch girls or start over. Unless you are the type that enjoys resetting the game and starting fresh repeatedly, you probably will complete the game once and rarely touch it again.

These experiences may be harmful or scarring, but like in the game, the girls get up, wounded, and make their way back to grandma's house. The whole story is about growing up. Letting your curiousity getting the better of you, getting wounded, but growing up a little. The path is a safe life without exploration. There is no harm, but neither do you learn anything. That is why you get a failure screen when you do not encounter the wolf.As for it's length, if you just buzz through the main task at hand, it is very short and you also miss a lot of added story. Each girl has items and unlockables. There is also 144 "flower coins" to collect if you so chose. In my opinion, the replay value only lasts as long as there is something that you missed, which just to note that the forest is randomly generated each time so finding everything will be a challange if you switch girls or start over. 												One of the most frequent criticisms of The Path is that it's not really "a game". And it's not. If you want a capital-G Game, look elsewhere. But does that need to be a criticism?What is it, then, if not a game? It's an experiential marvel. The only game I've ever seen with more atmosphere than The Path is the similarly un-game-like Dear Esther. While the theme of Little Red Riding Hood is so incredibly overdone in interactive storytelling circles (though few have made it to commercial release), The Path has an interesting enough take on it to be worthwhile. The characterisation is superb, although you have to search for it and even then it's expressed in a very minimal fashion. Each of the girls is likeable but flawed, and, without wanting to spoil too much, each one is ultimately undone by her flaw. While not a game in the ludic sense, interactivity does play a vital part of the experience, creating a sense of "discovering" the story and also creating emotional resonance by making the player complicit in sealing the girls' fates.The negative sides of the game are that sometimes atmosphere takes precedence over technical considerations. Sometimes the text that's communicating the story is illegible because it doesn't contrast strongly enough with the background, and sometimes the game just gets too dark to see what's going on, which I guess is supposed to be scary, but just ends up being frustrating.I can't recommend this without qualification, because it's not for everyone. Indeed, that's one of its strongest points! If you're interested in something that isn't quite a "game" in the traditional sense, are willing to put effort into engaging with it rather than having everything neatly presented to you, and your narrative sensibilities tend toward feeling rather than thinking, it's definitely worth a look.

												The Path is certainly a different gaming experience. A modern, gothic take on the classic Red Riding Hood Tale that articulates the dark cautionary elements quite well in subtle ways.The game has but one objective: Go to grandmother's. Upon doing so, this means you've somehow lost the game, so as it turns out, you are actually encouraged to disobey the rules, and adventure into the dark, dreary forest, interacting with objects in the woods, skipping freely, getting completely lost. Eventually, you, as one of six 'Red' girls, will find what represents the Wolf, in one of it's various incarnations. Upon meeting the wolf, you are taken back to the path, completely desolate and somber as you tread quietly to grandmother's in the rain. There, grandmother's house is no longer a sweet old lady's cottage but an absolute mind-♥♥♥♥ where you die, but you technically succeed in the game.While the game is completely open to interpretation, and is more art-focused, this reward of defeat, especially after a character has been presumably injured, molested, or otherwise attacked, raises a few questions, considering rather than being able to outsmart the wolf, once you are locked into the animation, there is no way of fighting back. You essentially play 6 victims. Again, this is more of an artistic form of story telling, but it still raises a few questions. Overall, visually, the game is appropriately sharp and goregous with a bit of an aesthetic to intice gamer-cult followings, and the soundtrack is fascinating and at times intensley dark. With so many themes and theories out there, this is a game for anyone who's looking for a different gaming experience, or for someone starting out in indie gaming. Or, simply for anyone into either gothic things or fairy tales.

With The Path, that is surprisingly hard to answer."Yes" if you are the type of gamer that likes something different from everything else you've played, won't let technical flaws distract you from immersing yourself in a well developed game world and enjoy stories with a dark side."No" if you have a short attention span that demands action be part of all gaming, tend to call things "pretentious" that others call "artsy", can't stand to be limited to an all female cast of playable characters or don't have a penchant for the macabre.Let me be more specific. Fortunately I never got permanently stuck, but there were several times that had me holding my breath. Aside from that, the slow pacing left me tapping my foot at times. Each character moves at a different speed which, in my opinion, doesn't add anything positive to the game. It just makes playing all of the slower characters less enjoyable. There are also certain locations where the ability to run is disabled. For that reason alone I found myself trying to avoid these locations even though otherwise they were often the most interesting places.With all that said, don't count The Path out yet. Its atmosphere is one to get lost in. The art style fits well and is altered heavily at times throughout the game to help heighten the feeling they are going for. The music perfectly matches what's going on and is hauntingly memorable. The stories told in this non-linear open world format are engrossing, if a bit too steeped in symbolism for my taste.Overall, it feels like the type of first game an independent developer would put out: Rough around the edges but a bright eyed, inspired piece of art that isn't afraid to test the boundaries of what a video game is.

												This is a beautiful game. It is purposefully abstract and I am excited about the potential for this style of storytelling in video games in the future.This is from the Tale of Tales creator Michael, as a response to a player's question - "in the midst of all of the individual interpretations, what was the story the creator's had in mind?":"This ambiguity and lack of resolution is exactly why we love the interactive medium so much. And why we think it is the medium of the new generation, the new century. It offers a way of trying to come to terms with the fact that truth does not exist anymore, that reality itself has been obscured by all the images we make of it, etc. Personally I follow the guidance of 19th century writer Alfred Jarry in this context. He invented 'Pataphysics, the science that "transcends metaphysics as metaphysics transcends physics". In short, it is a view of reality that simply accepts that everything that can be imagined is true. And more importantly, perhaps, that it is true simultaneously. So, something can be both black and white at the same time. I think interactive media offer us a way of creating artworks that embrace this ambiguity.So, even more important than the fact that every person's interpretation of The Path is perfectly valid, is the fact that this interpretation can be different every time you play, or even change after you stop playing. For me, it's more about the potential of meaning, than about a single conclusion. I think this comes from my dissatisfaction with language as a tool to describe reality. A painting or a piece of music have always felt more "true" to me than a page from the encyclopedia, or even a philosopher's theory."

Posted: January 4, 2015
												The Path is centered around six sisters, each one a different Red Riding Hood that the player can take control of on the walk to their grandmother's house. Players are originally instructed to stay on the path on the way there. Upon reaching grandmother's house, players are treated with an eerily empty house, a mysterious rocking chair, and a pale old woman in bed with a stuffed wolf lingering nearby. Or, should they stray off the path, they encounter objects that inspire their chosen character to relive unpleasant memories. Gather enough of these memories and your character will encounter the dreaded wolf. Unfortunately, what could have been an intriguing exploration game with a unique underlying concept is rendered more trouble than its worth by poorly designed gameplay. Each character you play as seems to move slower than the last, causing the game to suffer from terribly boring stretches of walking that seem to be taking you no where. The forest has very few noticeable landmarks or interesting sites to discover. I often found myself walking for long stretches of time, encountering absolutely nothing of interest. On top of the drearily slow pacing, the moment you start to feel like you're moving a little bit faster the camera swings to an inhospitable angle.Overall, the Path has a pleasantly creepy vibe to it. The music is often discordant and mixed with child-like singing and chanting. The air is foggy and the forest is dark. The hallways of the grandmother's house are large and imposing and there's a sense of foreboding whether you stay on the path or adventure off of it. The memories you find are unnerving and just a little bit haunting. In terms of atmosphere, the Path is a clear winner. However, the poor controls make even turning your character clumsy and awkward. The game quickly becomes so tedious that it loses what charm it originally had going for it.There's something to be said for the relaxation that comes with a good walking simulator. Many people debate over whether or not these type of "artistic experiences" qualify as true video games, but I believe that laid-back games that focus on exploration are just as valid a media as high-action platformers and shooters. As a genre, walking simulators often rely on some of the underlooked aspects of a good game: character, environment, and atmosphere. However, they are, first and foremost, intended to be played as video games and, as such, are required to maintain a certain level of playability that the Path fails to achieve.

It's very rare for a piece of media to successfully handle this type of open-ended interpretation. It's like the developers watched Jacob's Ladder (or any other horror-acid-trip film), was inspired by it, but then had no freaking clue how to piece together a coherent story while maintaining a sense of mystery. Also, lots and lots of scene flashes and twisted, topsy-turvy environments that force a supposed sense of symbolism. The game loves spewing nonsensical visual vomit masquerading as yet more symbolism across your screen. 												This game is one of my favorites. I don't normally like "walking simulators", but this one is very good. The story is you control 1 of 6 girls who go to grandma's house. The only rule being, "stay on the path" but you of course, as Little Red Riding Hood, say "screw that" and walk off the path where adventure and intrigue lie. Now the horror comes in when you run into your "wolf" (which isn't always a wolf) and end up knocked out in front of grandma's house. As you travel through grandma's house you feel goosebumps as you find out the fate of your young heorine. However, this game isn't all fun and roses, there are some development issues that must be mentioned. Each girl is super slow, and there is no map to the forest which is huge! It's very easy to get lost when trying to find an item that you know belongs to a particular sister. Also, when you encounter the wolf, you cannot run. You also get penalized for running by having the camera zoom out making it harder to see. The game can be laggy and buggy at times as well. But if you like games that are super artsy and are a sucker for off the cuff "Little Red Riding" stories then by all means spend your dollars. I think this game has great replay value and is one of the best "Tale of Tales" has to offer. 7/10

Posted: January 10, 2016
												The Path, from the recently and unfortunately departed Tale Of Tales, is a peculiar and perhaps polarizing experience that relies less on traditional gameplay functions and more on the player's curiosity and willingness to deviate from instruction. A unique take on the Red Riding Hood tale, you choose one of several young girls and are instructed to head to your grandmother's house without deviating from the established path in the forest. However, such things are never so simple.If you like, you're welcome to obey the rules and keep to the safety of the titular Path. That's not where anything interesting happens, however. By diverting into the woods, each girl has a chance of finding a series of reminders that illuminate their past, some of which are more traumatic than others. As there are several Red Riding Hoods, so are there multiple Big Bad Wolves, all of whom intervene in a given Red's life in their own unique ways. By the way, let me add a trigger warning for what I think was an implied sexual assault in one of the stories.The forest, its few inhabitants, the relics there, and the experiences following your discoveries upon your eventual arrival at grandma's are all beautifully rendered, and accompanied by a haunting, if limited in variety, soundtrack. The Path's decision to eschew dialogue for visual cues and symbolism helps get your imagination going, but at the same time makes certain sections more unclear than they ought to be. Even though the game quickly grew on me, even I had a few bouts of frustration between getting lost or being unsure what to do at certain points. Still, I enjoyed all the room left for interpretation with all the scenarios, and am still on the fence as to whether all the Reds are their own entities, if they're aspects of the same person (as they spread across a range of ages), or if they're something else entirely.The Path is definitely a game with rather niche appeal, but if you're willing to let yourself get lost in a world for a bit, several times over, I'd say it's worth a look.

												As it seems in the video game world, games heavily carried not by it's gameplay but by it's story and experience seem to be on the rise.The Path is one of these games.Extremely simple controls, as all you're given the option is to walk. In order to interact, you release the forward key. Gamers who are easily put off by a slow-pace, lack of action, and/or lower end graphics, I suggest you stop reading now, and shop elsewhere on Steam. However if you're a fan of exploration, experimentation, and a psychological approach on the horror genre, then by all means, keep reading.This is in fact a horror game, despite the lack of actual jump scares or a monster chasing you. The Path is unique that instead- you're chasing the monster. Play one of the six sisters who is tasked to bring your sick grandmather some wine and bread, but by all means, don't stray off the path- or so, as the game warns you. Despite the game's warning, you won't be rewarded unless you go on the path less travelled and go in search of the sister's wolf, unique to her. To avoid spoilers, I will break down the experience without actually delving into the story outside of;There's little to no voice acting. There's limited reading as each sister makes a remark on each object you do come across, as well as meeting her wolf. This minilmalist approach helps you get into the mindset of the sister, and what personality drives her to her decisions. Once meeting the wolf and finally arriving to grandmother's house are you treated with discovering the consequences of growing up and a bookend to that sister's story. Much like a silent film noted and influenced with a mix of an independent arthouse and a creepy horror film, enough is left unsaid to allow the players attempt to connect the pieces together. This leads to deep discussions creating webs around the game of everyone's different but meaningful and personal experiences. The Path is ultimately unique, memorable, and gorgeous in concept and haunting in it's hidden messages. This game is not for everyone, but for those who've fond memories of finding an old book to dust off to read of the dark fairy tales of once ago. This game is for those who can handle strong adult themes that can unrattle those sensitive to graphic truths of the real world. I bought this game the first year it came out, and even today I find myself going back to it. Well worth my money, and time, over and over again.

Posted: November 3, 2013
												The Path is an interactive experience that strides the line between a game and an artistic exposition. The setting is a journey to your grandmother's house by 6 young girls who are told to "follow the path" while the endless forest on the sides taunts you in. Each female protagonist, at different stages of puberty, get to explore and find specific objects and areas that trigger memories and thoughts while collecting 144 flowers.The entire exploration experience is a premise to encounter a unique metaphoric wolf or demon, that transforms the girls and throws them at gates of the fabled grandma's house, where a nightmarish sequence seals each chapter. From a narrative perspective, the experience builds upon your personal interpretation of each encounter and memory, and it is deciphered in your own mind rather than being explicit and direct. The atmosphere is tense but lacks the immediate feel of dread, while using music and sound effects to control the experience. If you run for too long, the gathering flowers disappear and the music becomes intense and foreboding, and if you arrive at set piece your are forced to walk, and so forth. The graphics are serviceable, with unique character designs and attention to minor details; a good example is the receding city scape in the opening, or how the the path disappears once you delve deeper into the forest. Each character gets its own set of animation for all movements and interactions, and the music albeit repetitive, does contribute to the atmosphere giving hints to special encounters and sets. The Path does require a personal emotional investment, something that many will forfeit. If you are willing to go through it, do not expect a satisfying resolution or an ending, as the journey is the game, there are no achievements or victories once the girls' paths are explored. 3/5

												I don't recommend The Path, but I will say that  I've never played anything else like it and the story and the characters did stick with me after I completed it. It's interesting, but it's definitely not worth $10. Catch if it goes on sale for a dollar or two if it interests you. The problem is that there is hardly enough actual gameplay to qualify it as a game. The only thing you can do in The Path is walk or run. The video makes it look like you're interacting with items, while you're actually just watching the characters do the interacting. Seriously, the way you pick up an object is by releasing the "walk" key and standing still so the girl can go on to interact with whatever you've stopped her near. I get that Tale of Tales was trying to tell us a story in an original way, but they don't seem to have an understanding of the importance of immersion. I probably would have loved the game if I actually felt like I was controlling the characters and discovering the secrets of the forest with them, but instead the game just left me feeling disconnected. When you finally do reach grandmother's house, your "reward" is an agonizingly slow walk and some flickering, jumpy cutscenes. Some of the sisters endings didn't even make sense, even with 100% level completion. People may try to gloss that over by saying it's "artsy" or "deep," but in reality it's just bad writing and poor design.

												This game is incredibly lovely and quite a tricky interpretation. It's unlike all games I have ever played before and I deeply wish more games had such an effective story line and deeply involved characters. There's no right or wrong way to play. There's no way to cheat. Everything is a metaphor. Everything is a message. The message I gathered?: At any age, you may come across a time you are faced with a fork in the road. You know to never break the rules, but if you choose to do so, you exit your comfort zone and travel into the unknown.
